title: Trump argues al-Baghdadi’s killing holds greater significance than U.S. raid that killed Osama bin Laden in 2011
text:
President Donald Trump said the U.S. military raid that took out Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is a bigger deal than the 2011 killing of al Qaeda founder Osama bin Laden during the Obama administration.

From the MarketWatch archives (May 2011): DNA tests confirm death of bin Laden

Plus (May 2011): Osama bin Laden had staked his claim to history long ago

Trump was detailing the operation during an announcement at the White House.

The president acknowledged that the death of bin Laden was significant, but he said he believes the death of al-Baghdadi is even bigger news.

Trump claimed that bin Laden — whose militant group was associated with the truck-bomb attack on the World Trade Center in 1993, along with attacks targeting U.S. forces and facilities, and allies, in 1992 in Aden, Yemen; in 1995, in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, in 1998; and in the Aden harbor, again in Yemen, in 2000 — hadn’t become a global name in terrorism until the terrorist attacks against domestic U.S. targets on Sept. 11, 2001.

White House/Pete Souza President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, along with members of the national-security team including Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, receive an update on Operation Neptune's Spear, the mission that killed Osama bin Laden, in the White House Situation Room on May 1, 2011.

The president said that situation stood in contrast to that of al-Baghdadi, who, said Trump, was responsible for building a caliphate.

MarketWatch contributed to this Associated Press report.
